vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(msg.sender == nominatedOwner, "You must be nominated before you can accept ownership");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(msg.sender == owner, "Only the contract owner may perform this action");
vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-custom-error-not-require

vulnerability_findings.message: Consider using custom errors as they are more gas efficient while allowing developers  to describe the error in detail using NatSpec.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(msg.sender == nominatedOwner, "You must be nominated before you can accept ownership");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(msg.sender == owner, "Only the contract owner may perform this action");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-short-revert-string
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code: require(msg.sender == deployer, "Only the deployer can invoke this");
vulnerability_findings.message: Shortening revert strings to fit in 32 bytes will decrease gas costs for deployment and  gas costs when the revert condition has been met.

vulnerability_findings.name: solc-version
vulnerability_findings.message:
Detected issues with version pragma in MockMigration.sol:
	- pragma solidity^0.5.16 (MockMigration.sol#3): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.5.16 (MockMigration.sol#43): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.5.16 (MockMigration.sol#82): it allows old versions

vulnerability_findings.name: low-level-calls
vulnerability_findings.message:
Low level call in BaseMigration.returnOwnership (MockMigration.sol#53-68):
	-(success) = forContract.call(payload) MockMigration.sol#57
	-(legacySuccess) = forContract.call(legacyPayload) MockMigration.sol#64

vulnerability_findings.name: naming-convention
vulnerability_findings.message: Parameter '_owner' of Owned. (MockMigration.sol#10) is not in mixedCase

vulnerability_findings.name: naming-convention
vulnerability_findings.message: Parameter '_owner' of Owned.nominateNewOwner (MockMigration.sol#16) is not in mixedCase

vulnerability_findings.name: naming-convention
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code:
function _onlyOwner() private view {

        require(msg.sender == owner, "Only the contract owner may perform this action");
vulnerability_findings.message: Function 'Owned._onlyOwner' (MockMigration.sol#33-35) is not in mixedCase

vulnerability_findings.name: naming-convention
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code:
function _requireDeployer() private view {

        require(msg.sender == deployer, "Only the deployer can invoke this");
vulnerability_findings.message: Function 'BaseMigration._requireDeployer' (MockMigration.sol#70-72) is not in mixedCase

errors: exception (RuntimeError: Source map error, unknown name(SHR) or instr_name(INVALID))

vulnerability_findings.name: External Call To User-Supplied Address (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A call to a user-supplied address is executed.
An external message call to an address specified by the caller is executed. Note that the callee account might contain arbitrary code and could re-enter any function within this contract. Reentering the contract in an intermediate state may lead to unexpected behaviour. Make sure that no state modifications are executed after this call and/or reentrancy guards are in place.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: Integer Arithmetic Bugs (SWC 101)
vulnerability_findings.message:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation. 
Classification: SWC-101

vulnerability_findings.name: State access after external call (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Read of persistent state following external call
The contract account state is accessed after an external call to a user defined address. To prevent reentrancy issues, consider accessing the state only before the call, especially if the callee is untrusted. Alternatively, a reentrancy lock can be used to prevent untrusted callees from re-entering the contract in an intermediate state.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: External Call To User-Supplied Address (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A call to a user-supplied address is executed.
An external message call to an address specified by the caller is executed. Note that the callee account might contain arbitrary code and could re-enter any function within this contract. Reentering the contract in an intermediate state may lead to unexpected behaviour. Make sure that no state modifications are executed after this call and/or reentrancy guards are in place.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: Multiple Calls in a Single Transaction (SWC 113)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Multiple calls are executed in the same transaction.
This call is executed following another call within the same transaction. It is possible that the call never gets executed if a prior call fails permanently. This might be caused intentionally by a malicious callee. If possible, refactor the code such that each transaction only executes one external call or make sure that all callees can be trusted (i.e. they’re part of your own codebase).
Classification: SWC-113

vulnerability_findings.name: State access after external call (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Write to persistent state following external call
The contract account state is accessed after an external call to a user defined address. To prevent reentrancy issues, consider accessing the state only before the call, especially if the callee is untrusted. Alternatively, a reentrancy lock can be used to prevent untrusted callees from re-entering the contract in an intermediate state.
Classification: SWC-107
